{{TennisEventInfo|1993|Monte Carlo Open| | date=19 – 25 April | edition=87th | category=[[ATP Masters Series|ATP Super 9]] | prize_money=$1,400,000 | draw=64S/32D | surface=[[Clay court|Clay]] / Outdoor | location=[[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]] | venue=[[Monte Carlo Country Club]] | champs= {{flagicon|ESP}} [[Sergi Bruguera]] <ref name="ms">{{cite web|title=1993 Monte Carlo Men's Singles draw|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/scores/archive/monte-carlo/410/1993/draws?matchType=singles|website=www.atpworldtour.com|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP)}}</ref> | champd= {{flagicon|SWE}} [[Stefan Edberg]] / {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Petr Korda]] <ref name="md">{{cite web|title=1993 Monte Carlo Men's Doubles draw|url=http://www.atpworldtour.com/en/scores/archive/monte-carlo/410/1993/draws?matchType=doubles|website=www.atpworldtour.com|publisher=[[Association of Tennis Professionals]] (ATP)}}</ref> }}
The '''1993 Monte Carlo Open''' was a men's [[tennis]] tournament played on [[Clay court|outdoor clay courts]]. It was the 87th edition of the [[Monte Carlo Masters|Monte Carlo Open]], and was part of the [[ATP Masters Series|ATP Super 9]] of the [[1993 ATP Tour]]. It took place at the [[Monte Carlo Country Club]] in [[Roquebrune-Cap-Martin]], France, near [[Monte Carlo]], [[Monaco]], from 19 April through 25 April 1993.
==Review== [[Sergi Bruguera]] won his first title of the year. The Spaniard, 11th seed, defeated French rising star [[Cédric Pioline]] in 97 minutes. Sergi defeated Cedric in straight sets, 7–6, 6–0.
The top 2 players in the world, [[Jim Courier]] and [[Pete Sampras]], were absent from the tournament. Only four seeds failed to win their first round matches: [[Fabrice Santoro]], [[Henrik Holm]], [[Karel Nováček]], and [[Arnaud Boetsch]]. The top eight players all received byes into round two. The highest seeded player not to make it into the third round was second seed [[Boris Becker]]. He was defeated by Swiss player [[Marc Rosset]]. Other casualties in the second round were [[Guy Forget]], [[Michael Stich]], and [[Goran Ivanišević]]
In the third round, only one seed, [[Petr Korda]], lost to an unseeded player; however, seeded players [[Richard Krajicek]] and [[Ivan Lendl]] lost to fellow seeds [[Andrei Medvedev]] and [[Sergi Bruguera]] respectively. A qualifier managed to advance to the final eight. The quarter final draw was:
*[[Stefan Edberg]] [1] vs [[Andrei Medvedev]] [7] *[[Cédric Pioline]] vs [[Jonas Svensson (tennis)|Jonas Svensson]] [WC] *[[Sergi Bruguera]] v vs [[Carlos Costa (tennis)|Carlos Costa]] [14] *[[Thomas Muster]] [8] vs [[Àlex Corretja]] [Q]
[[Stefan Edberg]], [[Cédric Pioline]], and [[Thomas Muster]] all eased through into the semi-finals. However, the other match lasted a little longer, as [[Sergi Bruguera]] defeated [[Carlos Costa (tennis)|Carlos Costa]] 7–6, 6–2.
In semi-finals, Pioline defeated Edberg in straights, while Bruguera scraped by Muster 6–4, 1–6, 7–6, saving match points. After over and hour and a half of tennis however, Bruguera was victorious defeating the Frenchman in straights.
Bruguera won his second title at Monte Carlo in 3 years, and was his final win in a Masters final.
The tournament, despite his loss in the final, started Pioline's long career.
==Champions== ===Men's Singles=== {{main|1993 Monte Carlo Open – Singles}} {{flagicon|ESP}} '''[[Sergi Bruguera]]''' defeated {{flagicon|FRA}} [[Cédric Pioline]], 7–6<sup>(7–2)</sup>, 6–0
===Men's Doubles=== {{main|1993 Monte Carlo Open – Doubles}} {{flagicon|SWE}} '''[[Stefan Edberg]]''' / {{flagicon|CZE}} '''[[Petr Korda]]''' defeated {{flagicon|NED}} [[Paul Haarhuis]] / {{flagicon|NED}} [[Mark Koevermans]], 3–6, 6–2, 7–6

It was the seventh championship race of the [[Open-wheel car|single-seater]], [[Electric car|electrically powered]] racing car series' [[2014–15 Formula E season|inaugural season]]. The race was won by [[Sébastien Buemi]], who became the first multiple race winner in the series. ==Report== ===Background=== For the second race in a row, the driver lineup was exactly the same as for [[2015 Long Beach ePrix|the previous race]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fiaformulae.com/en/news/2015/april/driver-line-up-the-same-for-monaco-eprix.aspx|title=Driver line-up the same for Monaco ePrix|date=29 April 2015|publisher=fiaformulae.com|accessdate=22 June 2015}} Fanboost was awarded to [[Nelson Piquet, Jr.]], [[Jean-Éric Vergne]] and [[Salvador Durán]].{{cite web|url=http://www.fiaformulae.com/en/news/2015/may/bird-vergne-and-piquet-win-fanboost-vote.aspx|title=Duran, Vergne and Piquet win FanBoost vote|date=9 May 2015|publisher=fiaformulae.com|accessdate=22 June 2015}} ==Classification== ===Qualifying=== {| class=wikitable style="font-size:95%" ! {{Tooltip|Pos.|Qualifying position}} ! {{Tooltip|No.|Number}} ! They are heavily influenced by [[Dream Theater]] and [[Symphony X]].{{citation needed|date=August 2007}} They released their albums in English and in Hungarian on different dates. ==Discography== ===Discography as Age of Nemesis=== * ''[[Nemesis (Age of Nemesis album)|Nemesis]]'' (1998) * ''[[Eden?]]'' (2002) (English) * ''[[Psychogeist]]'' (2006) (English) * ''[[Terra Incognita (Age of Nemesis album)|Terra Incognita]]'' (2007) (English) ===Discography as Nemesis=== * ''[[Nemesis (Age of Nemesis album)|Nemesis]]'' (1998) (Hungarian) * ''[[Abraxas (Age of Nemesis album)|Abraxas]]'' (1999) (Hungarian) * ''[[Eden?]]'' * ''[[For Promotional Use Only]]'' (2001) (Hungarian) * ''[[Terra Incognita (Age of Nemesis album)|Terra Incognita]]'' (2002) (Hungarian) * ''[[Terra Incognita (Age of Nemesis album)|Terra Incognita]]'' (2003) (English) * ''[[For Promotional Use Only II]]'' (2005) (Hungarian) ==Band line-up== ===Current members=== * Zoltán Kiss - Main vocals, rhythm guitars * Zoltán Fábián - Guitars * György Nagy - Keyboards * György Tolmacsov - Bass * Gábor Krecsmarik - Drums backing vocals ===Former members=== * Ákos Thorday - vocals (deceased) * György Pethe - bass * Mihály Szerecsen - drums * Laszlo Nagy - drums ==External links== * [http://www.ageofnemesis.com/ Age of Nemesis' official website] * [http://www.magnacarta.net/ Magna Carta (record label) website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Age of Nemesis}} [[Category:Hungarian heavy metal musical groups]] [[Category:Progressive metal musical groups]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1997]] [[Category:Musical quintets]] {{hungary-stub}} {{Europe-band-stub}}

{{small|(The Very Wise)}} | member_of = [[Federal Court of Malaysia]] | reports_to = | residence = | seat = [[Palace of Justice, Putrajaya|Palace of Justice]], [[Putrajaya]] | nominator = [[Prime Minister of Malaysia]] | appointer = [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]] | appointer_qualified = | termlength = mandatory retirement age at 65 or 66 (at request for minimal extension), extension retirement age at 68 or 70. | constituting_instrument = [[Constitution of Malaysia|Federal Constitution of Malaysia]] | formation = | inaugural = [[James Beveridge Thomson|James Thompson]]
{{small|as ''Chief Justice of the Federation of Malaya'' (1957)}} | deputy = | salary = [[Malaysian ringgit|MYR]] 25,000 per month | website = {{URL|http://www.kehakiman.gov.my/}} }} The '''Chief Justice of Malaysia''' (Malay: ''Ketua Hakim Negara''), also known as the Chief Justice of the Federal Court, is the office and title of the head of the Malaysian judiciary system. The title has been in use since 1994, and prior to this it was known as the [[Lord President of the Federal Court]]. The Chief Justice is the head of the [[Federal Court of Malaysia|Federal Court]], the highest court of Malaysia. It is the highest position in Malaysian judicial system followed by the [[President of the Court of Appeal of Malaysia]], [[Chief Judge of Malaya]], and the [[Chief Judge of Sabah and Sarawak]].{{cite web|url=http://www.kehakiman.gov.my/courts/maljudiciary.shtml#Ope|title=The Malaysian Judiciary: Operation of the court|publisher=Malaysian Court|accessdate=15 April 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110709144745/http://www.kehakiman.gov.my/courts/maljudiciary.shtml|archivedate=9 July 2011|deadurl=yes}} == Chief Justices of Malaysia == {{for|Lord Presidents before 1994|Lord President of the Federal Court}} * [[Abdul Hamid Omar]] (1994; previously Lord President) * [[Eusoff Chin|Mohamed Eusoff Chin]] (1994 to 2000) * [[Mohamed Dzaiddin Abdullah]] (2000 to 2003) * [[Ahmad Fairuz Abdul Halim]] (2003 to 2007) * [[Abdul Hamid Mohamad]] (2007 to 2008){{cite web|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=54447|title=Hamid is made the new CJ|publisher=Daily Express|date=6 December 2007|accessdate=10 December 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080625090723/http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=54447|archivedate=25 June 2008|deadurl=yes}} * [[Zaki Azmi]] (2008 to 2011) * [[Arifin Zakaria]] (2011 to 2017){{cite web|url=http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=/2011/9/6/nation/9431247&sec=nation|title=Arifin appointed Chief Justice|publisher=The Star|date=6 June 2011|accessdate=11 September 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120922224855/http://thestar.com.my/news/story.asp?file=%2F2011%2F9%2F6%2Fnation%2F9431247&sec=nation|archivedate=22 September 2012|deadurl=yes}} * [[Md Raus Sharif]] (2017 to 2018){{cite web|title=Md Raus appointed new Chief Justice|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/news/nation/2017/04/01/new-chief-justice/ |publisher=The Star |accessdate=1 April 2017 }} * [[Richard Malanjum]] (2018 to present){{cite web|url=https://www.bharian.com.my/berita/nasional/2018/07/448012/richard-malanjum-ketua-hakim-negara-yang-baharu|title=Richard Malanjum Ketua Hakim Negara yang baharu|work=Bernama|publisher=Berita Harian|date=11 July 2018|accessdate=12 July 2018}} == Living former Chief Justices == * [[Eusoff Chin|Mohamed Eusoff Chin]] * [[Mohamed Dzaiddin Abdullah]] * [[Ahmad Fairuz Abdul Halim]] * [[Abdul Hamid Mohamad]] * [[Arifin Zakaria]] * [[Md Raus Sharif]] == See also == * [[Courts of Malaysia]] * [[Royal Commission of Inquiry into the Lingam Video Clip|2007 Royal Commission]] == References == {{Asia-law-stub}} {{Malaysia-stub}} [[Category:Chief Justices of Malaysia|Chief Justices of Malaysia]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Use British English|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Christian Turney | image = Turney Svalbard.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 1973 | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | residence = | citizenship = British and Australian | nationality = | fields = [[Earth Science]]
[[Climatology]]
[[Geology]] | workplaces = [[University of New South Wales]]
[[University of Exeter]] | alma_mater = [[University of East Anglia]]
[[Royal Holloway, University of London]] | thesis_title = | thesis_url = | thesis_year = | doctoral_advisor = | academic_advisors = | doctoral_students = | notable_students = | known_for = | author_abbrev_bot = | author_abbrev_zoo = | influences = | influenced = | awards = Frederick White Prize (2014)
Laureate Fellowship (2010)
[[Bigsby Medal]] (2009)
[[Philip Leverhulme Prize]] (2008)
Sir Nicholas Shackleton Medal (2007)
J.G. Russell Award (2004) | footnotes = | spouse = | website = [http://www.christurney.com Chris Turney] }} '''Christian S. M. Turney''' [[Royal Society of Arts|FRSA]] [[Geological Society of London|FGS]] [[Royal Meteorological Society|FRMetSoc]] [[Royal Geographical Society|FRGS]] [[Higher Education Academy|FHEA]] is Professor of Climate Change and Earth Science at the [[University of New South Wales]].{{cite web|title=University of New South Wales|url=https://research.unsw.edu.au/people/professor-chris-turney|website=[[University of New South Wales]]|accessdate=1 December 2017}} Turney was educated at [[St Bede's School]], graduated from the [[University of East Anglia]] with a BSc in Environmental Science and completed his PhD at [[Royal Holloway, University of London]]. He was previously Professor of Physical Geography at the [[University of Exeter]]. He was awarded the J.G. Russell Award (2004) by the [[Australian Academy of Science]], the inaugural Sir Nicholas Shackleton Medal by the [[International Union for Quaternary Research]] in 2007, a [[Philip Leverhulme Prize]] in 2008, the [[Bigsby Medal]] of the [[Geological Society of London]] in 2009, and the Frederick White Prize by the [[Australian Academy of Science]] in 2014.{{cite web|title=Frederick White Prize winner, 2014|url=https://www.science.org.au/past-winners/2014-awardees#white|website=[[Australian Academy of Science]]|accessdate=6 March 2016}} In 2010, Turney was awarded a five-year [[Australian Research Council]] Laureate Fellowship. He has published four books{{cite web|title=Bones, Rocks and Stars: the Science of When Things Happened|url=https://www.palgrave.com/gp/book/9781403985996|website=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|accessdate=1 November 2017}}{{cite web|title=Ice, Mud and Blood: Lessons from Climates Past|url=https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3083413-ice-mud-and-blood|website=[[Palgrave Macmillan]]|accessdate=1 November 2017}}{{cite web|title=1912: The Year the World Discovered Antarctica|url=https://www.textpublishing.com.au/books/1912/|website=[[Text Publishing]]|accessdate=1 November 2017}}{{cite web|title=Iced In: Ten Days Trapped on the Edge of Antarctica|url=http://www.kensingtonbooks.com/book.aspx/35466|website=[[Kensington Books]]|accessdate=1 December 2017}} and more than 180 scientific research papers.{{cite web|title=Chris Turney Google Scholar|url=https://scholar.google.com.au/citations?user=BcKoMuoAAAAJ&hl=en|website=[[Google Scholar]]|accessdate=1 March 2018}} In 2013−14, Turney led a privately-funded expedition to the [[Antarctic]] called the Australasian Antarctic Expedition, in the "Spirit of Mawson", to investigate environmental changes across the region and communicate the value of scientific research. Scientific findings include the recognition of a 1965 [[Carbon-14]] peak preserved in "the Loneliest Tree in the World" and shrubs growing on [[Campbell Island, New Zealand]], that offer a possible marker for the proposed [[Anthropocene]] Epoch in the [[geological timescale]].{{cite web|title=Global peak in atmospheric radiocarbon provides a potential definition for the onset of the Anthropocene Epoch in 1965|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-018-20970-5|website=[[Scientific Reports]]|accessdate=1 March 2018}} On the return home, their ice-strengthened vessel became trapped by a substantial breakout of sea ice. His book on the expedition's discoveries and the team's experiences trapped by sea ice were published in ''Iced In: Ten Days Trapped on the Edge of Antarctica''.;{{cite web|title=Iced In: Ten Days Trapped on the Edge of Antarctica|url=http://www.kensingtonbooks.com/book.aspx/35466|website=[[Kensington Books]]|accessdate=1 December 2017}} in Australia and New Zealand, the same book was published under the name of ''Shackled''.{{cite web|title=Shackled|url=https://www.penguin.com.au/books/shackled-9780670079117|website=[[Penguin Books]]|accessdate=1 December 2017}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turney, Christian}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Alumni of the University of East Anglia]] [[Category:Alumni of Royal Holloway, University of London]] [[Category:Academics of the University of Exeter]] [[Category:University of New South Wales faculty]] [[Category:Fellows of the Geological Society of London]] [[Category:Fellows of the Royal Geographical Society]] [[Category:Antarctic scientists]] [[Category:1973 births]]

revision.text:
[[File:Ekd-lk-sachsen.png|thumb|Area of the Saxon Church]]
The '''Evangelical-Lutheran Church of Saxony''' (''Evangelisch-Lutherische Landeskirche Sachsens'') is one of 22 member Churches of the [[Evangelical Church in Germany]] (EKD), covering most of the state of [[Saxony]]. Its headquarters are in [[Dresden]], and its bishop (styled Bishop of Saxony<ref>The Bishop's title on his/her own [http://www.evlks.de/en/the_church/bishop/index.html home page].</ref>) has his or her seat at [[Meissen Cathedral]].
==Historical significance== Historically, its organisation became an example for other [[Protestant]] churches to be founded throughout [[Europe]], the so-called "Saxon model" of a church as introduced by [[Martin Luther]] itself. It was closely tied to the state, whereby the [[Elector of Saxony]] protected the evangelical faith in his jurisdiction. Since the Reformation, the [[Lutheran orthodoxy]] (the "purest form" of [[Lutheranism]]) prevailed among the general population in Saxony and was secured first by its Ernestine and later Albertine Wettin rulers. Beginning in the 17th century, [[Pietism]] also gained a significant following, especially among the working class.
==Parishioners== *1922: 4,509,000,<ref name="Müller-Rolli 1999 29">Sebastian Müller-Rolli in collaboration with Reiner Anselm, ''Evangelische Schulpolitik in Deutschland 1918–1958: Dokumente und Darstellung'', Göttingen: Vandenhoeck & Ruprecht, 1999, (=Eine Veröffentlichung des Comenius-Instituts Münster), p. 29. {{ISBN|3-525-61362-8}}.</ref> then by parishioners by far the biggest Lutheran church in Germany *2012: 764,000 *2013: 754,451<ref>[http://www.lutheranworld.org/sites/default/files/LWI-Statistics-2013-EN.pdf The Lutheran World Federation – 2013 Membership Figures] Lutheran World</ref> *2015: 713,648<ref>[http://www.ekd.de/download/kirchenmitglieder_2015.pdf Evangelische Kirche in Deutschland - Kirchemitgliederzahlen Stand 31.12.2015] EKD Januar 2017</ref>
==Practices== [[Ordination of women]] and [[blessing of same-sex unions]] were allowed.<ref>[http://www.evlks.de/aktuelles/nachrichten/31864.html Evlks.de:„Segnung von Paaren in Eingetragener Lebenspartnerschaft“ in Sachsen möglich (German)] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019081429/http://www.evlks.de/aktuelles/nachrichten/31864.html |date=2016-10-19 }}, 18 October 2016</ref>
==Notes== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.evlks.de/en/ The Lutheran Church in Saxony - homepage] (Eng.)
{{Hidden Regional Churches of the EKD}} {{Lutheran World Federation Churches}} {{Regional Protestant churches within the German Evangelical Church Confederation (1922–1933)}}

[[GMA Records]] | subsid = | owner = [[Felipe Gozon]], CEO | homepage = [http://www.gmanetwork.com/artistcenter gmanetwork.com/artistcenter] | dissolved = | footnotes = }} '''GMA Artist Center''' ('''Global Media Arts Artist Center''', also known as '''GMAAC''') is a major talent agency and producer in the [[Philippines]] based in [[Metro Manila]] that was founded by [[Felipe Gozon]]. revision.text:
'''Globe Award''' is an international [[sustainability]] award which aims at encouraging and promoting the corporate and public sector, individual scientists as well as groups of innovator that have excelled in sustainable development in the world. Globe Award is a not-for-profit organisation with focuses on fostering sustainability in societies. Globe Award’s main goal boils down to inspire actors to take responsibility and act globally through awarding great cases within research, innovations, municipalities and companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globeaward.org/ |title=Home |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
The award is handed out in 4 categories: ''Sustainability Research, Sustainability Innovation, Sustainable City'' and ''Sustainability Reporting''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globeaward.org/globe_award_2011 |title=2011 |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
==Globe Award values==
1. ''Sustainable development''
Driving sustainability by recognising and awarding sustainability champions from around the world is crucial. This is about understanding the consequences of nowadays’s activities and believing in global collaboration to reach solutions to safeguard humanity’s welfare today and in the future.
2. ''Impact''
It is significant to create behavioural change through rewording unique solutions that can be implemented in order to make a change.
3. ''Transparency''
The Globe Award jury groups run the selection process equally independently.
4. ''Innovation''
Honouring tomorrow's leaders develops innovative solutions to the world’s sustainability challenges. Innovative business perspectives are considered as well as people, planet and profit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globeaward.org/about-globe-award |title=About |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
The noted and internationally recognized 4 groups of jury consist of experts in sustainability from all over the world. They select one winner in each category independently and on objective grounds. There is the over-all jury chairman who along with the Globe Award secretariat, keeps that the process and selection of applications is obeyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globeaward.org/jury |title=Jury 2011 |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref> Globe Award is an initiative by Globe Forum.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globeforum.com/ |title=Start2011 |publisher=GlobeForum |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
==History==
When started in 2007, Globe Award was a Swedish CSR Award. After two years of success in Sweden, Globe Forum decided to go further with Globe Award. Struggling in making a difference and increasing awareness towards sustainable development in all societies, it made sense in creating Globe Award a truly global prize focusing on sustainability, instead of CSR, starting from 2009. The award ceremony takes place annually in [[Stockholm]]. The initiative is supported by H.R.H. [[Victoria, Crown Princess of Sweden]]. Despite the world-wide edition, there was a national edition in [[Poland]]. It took place in Gdansk in 2009. The Globe Award Polish Edition was handed out in two categories: Sustainability Innovation and Sustainable City.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globeaward.org/polish_edition/en/about.html |title=About |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
==Former winners==
'''2007'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globeaward.org/globe-award-2007 |title=2007 |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
* ''Best CSR Research'' – Sustainability Research Group of the Stockholm School of Economics, Sweden * ''Best CSR Entrepreneur'' – Scandinavian Biogas, Sweden * ''Best CSR Company'' – [[SKF]], Sweden
'''2008'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globeaward.org/globe-award-2008 |title=2008 |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
* ''Best CSR Research'' – Sustainable Investment Research Platform, SIRP, at Umeå School of Business, Sweden * ''Best CSR Entrepreneur'' – Rehact AB, Sweden. An honorary diploma was given to Umbilical Design AB. * ''Best Integration of CSR in Business Operations'' – [[Electrolux]], Sweden
'''2009'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globeaward.org/globe_award_2009 |title=2009 |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
* ''Sustainability Research'' – [[Nimbkar Agricultural Research Institute]] (NARI),India * ''Sustainability Innovation'' – [[Tesla Motors]], USA * ''Sustainable City'' – [[Cardiff]], UK * ''Sustainability Reporting'' – [[Novo Nordisk]], Denmark
'''2010'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.globeaward.org/88 |title=2010 |publisher=Globe Award |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}}</ref>
* ''Sustainability Research'' – Antrix Corporation ISRO, India * ''Sustainability Innovation'' – [[Abdul Razaque]], Pakistan * ''Sustainable City'' – [[Curitiba]], Brazil * ''Sustainability Reporting'' – CLP, Hong Kong
Globe Award together with [[World Bank]] has been building an independent, global foundation which will be awarding annually outstanding sustainable cases in the world.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * {{cite web|author= |url=http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/pressroom/globe_forum/pressrelease/view/companies-and-corporations-with-sustainability-reporting-can-be-nominated-to-win-international-award-481114 |title=Globe Forum – Companies and corporations with Sustainability reporting can be... |publisher=Mynewsdesk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.mynewsdesk.com/se/pressroom/globe_forum/pressrelease/view/the-world-bank-in-international-partnership-to-create-a-new-global-award-for-sustainable-communities-400719 |title=Globe Forum – The World Bank in International Partnership to Create a New Global... |publisher=Mynewsdesk |date= |accessdate=2012-01-07}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.globeaward.org/globe_award_2009 |title=Globe Award 2009 |publisher=Globe Award |accessdate=2012-01-07}}
